The link to the MIT OCW notes doesn't explain why the first derivative WRT space is the rate of heat flow. This seems inherent to the differential equation, and also comes up in electromagnetism and quantum mechanics as current conservation. In particular, in quantum mechanics it can be used to prove that the probability density of an observable quantity maintains the value of unity as time evolves because the spatial derivative of the wave equation levels off at the boundary, whether that boundary is infinity or an infinitely high wall of potential. This explains why we chose the derivative WRT space = 0 boundary conditions in quantum mechanics, as well as here (can't lose heat, can't lose probability density of a hermitian solution). Anyone else wonder what is "c" in 4:00 and then what is c^2? I stopped the video and did a bit of algebra. I hope this helps someone else. We know the temperature at whatever point x starting from a time step 0 to be sin(x). If we use this recursively plus the fact that any future temperature value is the previous value plus (in this case minus because of the sign from second derivative) the rate of change times the time elapsed: T(x,0+dt) = T(x,0)-a*T(x,0+dt)*dt = sin(x)-a*sin(x)*dt=sin(x)*(1-a*dt). let's define c:=(1-a*dt). Thus for T(x,0+dt+dt)=T(x,2dt)=sin(x)-a*sin(x)*dt-a*(sin(x)-a*sin(x)*dt)*dt. Collect terms and you get sin(x)*(1-a*dt-a*dt-a^2*dt^2). The stuff in the last parenthesis is just c^2.

This video is amazing! But it leaves some things unmentioned. Adiabatic boundaries (dT/dx=0) are not the only boundary conditions in heat equations. Linear temperature profile T=c*x is perfctly good solution in some situations. It just states that the system is stationary and the boundaries are in constant temperatures  Uniform temperature distribution is not the stationary solution of any other system than isolated systems. For the purpose of the video it doesn't matter tough.

I do have one minor quibble, though: you can have solutions where dT/dx ≠ 0 at the ends by maintaining a constant temperature on each end of the rod. For example, the solution which "fails to describe actual heat flow" (7:17) actually describes the temperature distribution inside a wall where the interior is at one temperature and the exterior is at another temperature, and you can use it to figure out how much heat is flowing through the wall. We physicists & engineers do think about such solutions frequently. (I can understand why you didn't want to get into these weeds in an introductory video, though.)

Note that that thing about the slope having to be 0 at the edges is not quite general! It is the case for when there is no heat entering or leaving the bar, but if, say, the bar is connected to a reservoir kept at 20°C at the left end, then the boundary condition becomes that T(0, t) = 20.

This becomes relevant for things like that linear solution Grant showed. As that solution becomes physically relevant for the case of boundary conditions where T(0, t) and T(L, t) are equal to some constants. Which would reflect a bar connecting two reservoirs with heat flowing from the hot one to the cold one.

History question: Was decomposing a function into sine waves Fourier's idea, or was this already known and his contribution was applying the method to PDEs? On the one hand, it seems like people should have thought of Fourier series earlier since it was understood at least since Pythagoras that complex musical tones are made of simple harmonics. Also it's a pretty natural idea once you've invented Taylor series. On the other hand, studying Fourier series of the simplest of functions like f(x) = x very quickly yields the solution to the Basel problem, originally solved by Euler using a totally different method, which suggests nobody had studied them at all before Fourier himself.

Probably another thing to mention about using only working on "one example" is that most introductory PDE courses exclusively cover heat and wave equation due to their properties and difficulty alone. Working with equations beyond these requires the framework that these well studies problems give. Differential equations, and especially PDEs rarely occur ideally in nature, and understanding ideal cases and generalizing is effectively the only means we have to deal with what we find in nature. Another thing to consider was to contrast the solution with the first derivative boundary condition with a solution for the infinite number line that doesn't need a boundary condition. Because the way it is right now, it really seems like the sine solution is kinda confusing, since we didn't get to see what exactly it solved for.

EDIT: just to clarify a little more, what I'm talking about is that there's some cognitive dissonance with the solution for sine waves, since it's a valid mathematical solution that, from the narrative in the video, doesn't translate to any concrete scenario.
